title: Agent OS: A Micro-Architecture for AI Agents
summary: A comprehensive framework for architecting AI agents by decomposing them into three functional units: LPU (Language Processing Unit), I/O (Input/Output), and RAM (State). This approach emphasizes modularity, composability, and the separation of logic from state to create scalable and interoperable agentic workflows.

steps.reasoning: Standardizes agent design into manageable components (LPU, I/O, RAM) rather than ad-hoc scripts, mirroring the structure of an operating system.
Centralizes logic and decision-making by pooling models and prompts. This allows for easy swapping of models and prompt strategies without rewriting system code.
Enables the agent to interact with the real world (tools) and allows developers to visualize and debug internal processes (spyware).
Separates dynamic state from static logic, allowing the agent to maintain context, update variables, and evolve over a lifecycle.
Establishes the operational cycle: LPU processes prompt -> performs I/O -> updates RAM -> LPU processes new state.
Treats individual agents as black-box functions, enabling the construction of complex 'Agentic Workflows' by chaining outputs of one agent to inputs of another.
Identifies the critical need for agents to update their own state or logic based on performance metrics to evolve execution quality over time.

key_takeaways: The Agent OS architecture splits agents into LPU (Logic), I/O (Tools/Monitoring), and RAM (State).
Composability is the next level of abstraction, treating agents as modular functions to build complex workflows.
Separating RAM (State) from the LPU allows for explicit state management and autonomous operation.
Monitoring ('Spyware') is crucial; if you cannot measure the agent's internal state and outputs, you cannot improve it.
The architecture prioritizes modularity, enabling the rapid swapping of underlying models (e.g., GPT-4 to GPT-5) without refactoring.
